_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements:
 
(a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source;
 
Within the management and administrative roles of the Water Treatment Plant (WTP), responsibility has been defined to coordinate and implement the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and the overall development and management of the RMP is the responsibility of the City of Glendale, Water Services Department, Water Treatment Superintendent. 

Implementation of the requirements of the City of Glendale Process Safety Management (PSM)/Risk Management Program (RMP) elements is the responsibility of the Water Facility Supervisor with oversight from the Water Treatment Superintendent. The facility is also supported by a Safety Program Manager and Environmental Program Manager at the Water Services Division level. The City of Glendale has developed PSM/RMP program purpose, scope and requirements documents addressing all program elements required under the PSM/RMP regulations.
 
The City of Glendale has designated its water treatment plants as non-responding facilities; thus, its employees will not respond to accidental releases of regulated substances. The Water Facility Supervisor, with assistance from the Water Treatment Superintendent and Environmental Program Manager, is responsible for the annual review and update of the facility Emergency Response Plan (ERP). This includes conducting the annual coordination activities, annual notification drills, and establishing appropriate schedules and plans for field and tabletop exercises with outside emergency responders. The Environmental Program Manager is responsible for submittal of the ERP to the Arizona State Emergency Response Commission (AZSERC) as part of the Citys obligations under the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).

(b) The stationary source and r

as detectors within the building activate local alarm strobes and horns through the facility. The emergency scrubber will shut off upon detection of chlorine at the scrubber discharge, which is an indication the scrubber capacity has been exceeded; residual chlorine is contained within the building designed for this purpose.
 
The chlorine containers connected to the feed system banks are equipped with motorized Emergency Shutdown Devices connected directly to the container. The motorized control valves are remotely shutdown in an emergency, either manually or shutdown initiated automatically upon detection of a chlorine leak. The only pressurized source of chorine in the process is within the supply container and the small volume of piping between the container and control valve, and the vacuum regulating valve, which is connected directly immediately downstream of the motorized Emergency Shutdown Device. Flow out of the vacuum regulating valve to the downstream feed system (chlorinators and injection points) is continually under vacuum created by eductors at the finished water injection points. 
 
There is a multi-layer system in place to mitigate the extent of chlorine release from the process: (1) properly trained operators to safely handle chlorine and to operate and maintain the process equipment; (2) chlorine leak detectors located where chlorine is stored and/or used; (3) fail-safe equipment, design and installation of back-up safety equipment including emergency chlorine scrubber; and (4) an automated warning system that notifies both on-site and off-site personnel of a potential release. 

(d) The five-year accident history;
 
The facility has had no accidents meeting the EPA criteria requiring reporting under the five-year accident history. 

(e) The emergency response program;
 
The City of Glendale has developed and implemented an Emergency Planning and Response Program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The facility has

developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that addresses the RMP-required elements. The written ERP is based on the Arizona State Emergency Response Commissions EPCRA Facility Emergency Response Plan template that complies with other Federal contingency plan regulations consistent with the approach in the National Response Team's Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance (One Plan). The EPCRA ERP has been amended to address the additional ERP elements under EPA RMP, such as documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures (§68.95(a)(1)(ii)) and training for all employees in relevant procedures (§68.95(a)(3)).
  
The ERP for each facility is reviewed and updated at least annually, or more frequently due to changes at the facility or new information obtained from coordination activities, emergency response exercises, incident investigations, or other available information, and ensure that employees are informed of the changes.

The facility conducts and documents annual coordination activities and annual notification drills. As a non-responding facility, annual coordination includes consulting with local emergency response officials to establish appropriate schedules and plans for field and tabletop exercises; this requires that the facility request an opportunity to meet with the LEPC (or equivalent) and/or local fire department as appropriate to review and discuss those plans and schedule exercises. 

(f) Planned changes to improve safety.

The facility has recently completed revision of all PSM/RMP program documents and is in the process of electronically compiling all process safety information and records into an electronic filing system.
